justification: The article notes that during perceptual decision-making “the researchers observed the Centro-Parietal Positivity (CPP), an EEG indicator of evidence accumulation.”

measured_by: firing rate of neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP)
justification: Roitman and Shadlen “found that firing rate of neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP)… were similar to the way evidence for decision making accumulates,” linking LIP activity to the accumulation construct.
Describing the aDDM, the paper states that it “utilizes eye-tracking data as an external indicator of attention,” treating gaze measures as the operationalization of attentional allocation.

measured_by: peak amplitude of CPP at response
justification: O' Connell et al. tested whether “the peak CPP at the time the participant made the response was fixed,” using CPP amplitude to index the amount of evidence required to cross the decision threshold.

measured_by: firing-rate threshold in superior colliculus (SC) neurons
justification: Stine et al. reported that SC neurons “exhibited a burst dynamic… just before a response occurs,” and inhibiting SC altered the time needed to decide, indicating SC firing reaching a criterion represents the boundary construct.
The article contrasts CPP with LHB, noting that LHB “appears in the left hemisphere during response execution,” marking motor implementation rather than decision formation.

Weindel et al. used EMG, stating that “by measuring the duration of the EMG signal, this can be considered as the time of response execution,” thus employing EMG as the measure for the execution construct.
